elements.content: Aqueous Zn-based batteries (ZIBs) possess huge advantages in terms of high safety, low cost, and environmental friendliness. However, the lack of suitable cathodes with high-capacity, long-cycling, and high-rate capability limits their practical application. Herein, we present a highly crystalline one-dimensional π–d conjugated conductive metal–organic framework by coordinating ultrasmall 1,2,4,5-benzenetetramine (BTA) linkers with copper ions (Cu-BTA-H), as a cathode for ZIBs. The large ratio of active sites and dual redox mechanism of Cu-BTA-H, including the one-electron-redox reaction over copper ions (via Cu2+/Cu+) and the two-electron-redox reaction over organic ligands (via CN/C–N), effectively enhance its reversible capacity. Meanwhile, the abundant porosity, small band gap, high crystallinity, and stable coordination structure of Cu-BTA-H endow it with fast ion/electron transport and effectively hinder the dissolution of organic ligands during cycling, respectively. Consequently, Cu-BTA-H possesses a high reversible capacity of 330 mAh g–1 at 200 mA g–1 and excellent rate performance and long-cycle stability, with a high capacity of 106.1 mAh g–1 at 2.0 A g–1 after 500 cycles and a high Coulombic efficiency of ∼100%. The proposed conductive MOFs with dual redox-active sites provide an efficient approach for constructing fast, stable, and high-capacity energy storage devices.
elements.clean_text: Aqueous Zn-based batteries (ZIBs) possess huge advantages in terms of high safety, low cost, and environmental friendliness. However, the lack of suitable cathodes with high-capacity, long-cycling, and high-rate capability limits their practical application. Herein, we present a highly crystalline one-dimensional π-d conjugated conductive metal-organic framework by coordinating ultrasmall 1,2,4,5-benzenetetramine (BTA) linkers with copper ions (Cu-BTA-H), as a cathode for ZIBs. The large ratio of active sites and dual redox mechanism of Cu-BTA-H, including the one-electron-redox reaction over copper ions (via Cu2+/Cu+) and the two-electron-redox reaction over organic ligands (via CN/C-N), effectively enhance its reversible capacity. Meanwhile, the abundant porosity, small band gap, high crystallinity, and stable coordination structure of Cu-BTA-H endow it with fast ion/electron transport and effectively hinder the dissolution of organic ligands during cycling, respectively. Consequently, Cu-BTA-H possesses a high reversible capacity of 330 mAh g-1 at 200 mA g-1 and excellent rate performance and long-cycle stability, with a high capacity of 106.1 mAh g-1 at 2.0 A g-1 after 500 cycles and a high Coulombic efficiency of ~100%. The proposed conductive MOFs with dual redox-active sites provide an efficient approach for constructing fast, stable, and high-capacity energy storage devices.

elements.content: The ever-growing fossil fuel consumption and environmental pollution have triggered the exploration of reliable and low-cost battery systems for storing and utilizing renewable and clean energy sources. Among the various battery systems, aqueous zinc ion batteries (ZIBs) have been considered promising because of their high theoretical capacity (820 mAh gZn –1 or 5851 mAh cmZn –3), low redox potential (−0.76 V vs the standard hydrogen electrode), low cost, and the high safety of the metallic Zn anode in aqueous electrolytes. However, the unsatisfactory performance of typical cathode materials, in terms of poor cycling life, rate capability, and reversible capacity, seriously hinders the practical feasibility of ZIBs.
elements.clean_text: The ever-growing fossil fuel consumption and environmental pollution have triggered the exploration of reliable and low-cost battery systems for storing and utilizing renewable and clean energy sources. Among the various battery systems, aqueous zinc ion batteries (ZIBs) have been considered promising because of their high theoretical capacity (820 mAh gZn -1 or 5851 mAh cmZn -3), low redox potential (-0.76 V vs the standard hydrogen electrode), low cost, and the high safety of the metallic Zn anode in aqueous electrolytes. However, the unsatisfactory performance of typical cathode materials, in terms of poor cycling life, rate capability, and reversible capacity, seriously hinders the practical feasibility of ZIBs.

elements.content: Typical cathode materials for ZIBs include layered inorganic materials (e.g., MnO2, V2O5, etc.), small-molecule organic materials (e.g., carbonyl compounds, imine compounds, etc.), and Prussian blue analogues. For the layered inorganic materials, their huge volume variation/pulverization upon Zn2+ insertion/extraction inevitably deteriorates the cycling life. In comparison, the redox reaction in the organic cathodes is mainly achieved by the rearrangement of chemical bonds (e.g., −CO and −CN) rather than the inset/extraction of Zn2+ ions, which can effectively avoid the materials’ volume variation/pulverization. However, the dissolution of common small-molecule organic ligands into electrolytes severely hinders the stability of organic cathodes. In addition, the intrinsically poor electronic/ionic conductivity of these aforementioned cathode materials further limits the improvement of the batteries’ rate performances.
elements.clean_text: Typical cathode materials for ZIBs include layered inorganic materials (e.g., MnO2, V2O5, etc.), small-molecule organic materials (e.g., carbonyl compounds, imine compounds, etc.), and Prussian blue analogues. For the layered inorganic materials, their huge volume variation/pulverization upon Zn2+ insertion/extraction inevitably deteriorates the cycling life. In comparison, the redox reaction in the organic cathodes is mainly achieved by the rearrangement of chemical bonds (e.g., -CO and -CN) rather than the inset/extraction of Zn2+ ions, which can effectively avoid the materials' volume variation/pulverization. However, the dissolution of common small-molecule organic ligands into electrolytes severely hinders the stability of organic cathodes. In addition, the intrinsically poor electronic/ionic conductivity of these aforementioned cathode materials further limits the improvement of the batteries' rate performances.

elements.content: In comparison, conductive metal–organic framework materials (c-MOFs), which are constructed by coordinating metal ions (Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, etc.) and π-conjugated organic ligands (e.g., hexaaminobenzene), have been employed in high-rate lithium and sodium ion batteries, and the unique features of c-MOFs make them potentially suitable for ZIBs as well. On the one hand, the c-MOFs not only possess a tailorable pore structure and high specific surface area but also show excellent electrical conductivity (0.1–1000 S cm–1), owing to their abundant π–π/π–d conjugated structure and graphene-like delocalized electrons, which fundamentally provide a much enhanced electronic/ionic conductivity compared with the conventional MOF counterparts. On the other hand, the stable coordination structure of metal ions bonded with organic ligands in c-MOFs can effectively inhibit the leaching of organic ligands and thus improve their cycling stability. Of note, a high crystallinity for MOFs is very important to realize their excellent potential performances, and various methods, including the adjustment of reaction conditions (reactant concentration, reaction temperature, solvent kinds, etc.), an interface-assisted strategy, and and organic ligand replacement strategy, are adopted to achieve high-crystallinity MOFs.
elements.clean_text: In comparison, conductive metal-organic framework materials (c-MOFs), which are constructed by coordinating metal ions (Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, etc.) and π-conjugated organic ligands (e.g., hexaaminobenzene), have been employed in high-rate lithium and sodium ion batteries, and the unique features of c-MOFs make them potentially suitable for ZIBs as well. On the one hand, the c-MOFs not only possess a tailorable pore structure and high specific surface area but also show excellent electrical conductivity (0.1-1000 S cm-1), owing to their abundant π-π/π-d conjugated structure and graphene-like delocalized electrons, which fundamentally provide a much enhanced electronic/ionic conductivity compared with the conventional MOF counterparts. On the other hand, the stable coordination structure of metal ions bonded with organic ligands in c-MOFs can effectively inhibit the leaching of organic ligands and thus improve their cycling stability. Of note, a high crystallinity for MOFs is very important to realize their excellent potential performances, and various methods, including the adjustment of reaction conditions (reactant concentration, reaction temperature, solvent kinds, etc.), an interface-assisted strategy, and and organic ligand replacement strategy, are adopted to achieve high-crystallinity MOFs.

elements.content: Apart from these merits, the reversible metal ion storage in c-MOFs not only is associated with the bond rearrangement of the organic ligands, such as −CNH, −CO, etc. but also depends on the redox of the transition-metal ions, thus achieving multimechanism metal ion storage with a higher capacity. For example, a 2D Cu-based c-MOF using 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexahydroxytrimethylene hydrate as the organic ligand (Cu-HHTP) has been recently reported as a high-rate cathode for ZIBs, verifying the dual redox-active sites of organic ligands and Cu2+ ions in aqueous ZIBs. However, the low ratio of active −CO groups and the high content of inactive phenyl content in HHTP ligands in this c-MOF potentially compromise the advantages of the dual-mechanism Zn storage feature, resulting in an unsatisfactory capacity of only 189.2 mAh g–1. In addition, c-MOFs with −CO/–C–OH groups commonly possess stronger hydrophilicity than those composed of −CNH/–C–NH2 groups, which makes them easier to dissolve into aqueous electrolytes, significantly deteriorating their cycling performance, even with the help of the stabilizing effect of coordinated metal ions. Thus, c-MOFs with a high portion of −CNH terminal groups, which act as the primary Zn storage sites, and coordinated multivalent metal ions, as the secondary Zn storage sites, would be promising for achieving high capacity and satisfactory cycling stability in the meantime.

For example, a 2D Cu-based c-MOF using 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexahydroxytrimethylene hydrate as the organic ligand (Cu-HHTP) has been recently reported as a high-rate cathode for ZIBs, verifying the dual redox-active sites of organic ligands and Cu2+ ions in aqueous ZIBs. However, the low ratio of active -CO groups and the high content of inactive phenyl content in HHTP ligands in this c-MOF potentially compromise the advantages of the dual-mechanism Zn storage feature, resulting in an unsatisfactory capacity of only 189.2 mAh g-1. In addition, c-MOFs with -CO/-C-OH groups commonly possess stronger hydrophilicity than those composed of -CNH/-C-NH2 groups, which makes them easier to dissolve into aqueous electrolytes, significantly deteriorating their cycling performance, even with the help of the stabilizing effect of coordinated metal ions. Thus, c-MOFs with a high portion of -CNH terminal groups, which act as the primary Zn storage sites, and coordinated multivalent metal ions, as the secondary Zn storage sites, would be promising for achieving high capacity and satisfactory cycling stability in the meantime.

elements.content: Regarding this, we herein report a Cu-based c-MOF that is composed of ultrasmall 1,2,4,5-benzenetetramine (BTA) ligands and coordinated copper ions as the cathode for aqueous ZIBs. The adoption of the small molecule BTA effectively maximizes the portion of redox-active species (i.e., −CN−) and minimizes the inactive contents (i.e., the benzene group) in the c-MOFs. Meanwhile, the secondary redox of the transition-metal ions (Cu2+/Cu+) synergistically contributes to an additional capacity for Zn storage. Thus, a high reversible capacity of 330 mAh g–1 at 200 mA g–1 has been achieved for Cu-BTA. In addition, the unique porous structure, high electronic conductivity, and stable coordination structure of Cu-BTA with high crystallinity collaboratively contribute to both a high-rate capability and excellent cycling stability, showing a high capacity of 106.1 mAh g–1 at 2.0 A g–1 after 500 cycles with a Coulombic efficiency of ∼100%. The design of c-MOF-based cathodes with dual 0active sites can thus effectively enhance the energy density and durability of ZIBs.

Meanwhile, the secondary redox of the transition-metal ions (Cu2+/Cu+) synergistically contributes to an additional capacity for Zn storage. Thus, a high reversible capacity of 330 mAh g-1 at 200 mA g-1 has been achieved for Cu-BTA. In addition, the unique porous structure, high electronic conductivity, and stable coordination structure of Cu-BTA with high crystallinity collaboratively contribute to both a high-rate capability and excellent cycling stability, showing a high capacity of 106.1 mAh g-1 at 2.0 A g-1 after 500 cycles with a Coulombic efficiency of ~100%. The design of c-MOF-based cathodes with dual 0active sites can thus effectively enhance the energy density and durability of ZIBs.

elements.content: As depicted in a, Cu-BTA was synthesized by coordinating polymerization of 1,2,4,5-benzenetetramine (BTA) with Cu2+ ions in the presence of ammonia. In this process, the −NH– species are formed by deprotonation of −NH2 in the BTA ligands coordinated with Cu2+ ions in a square and planar manner, forming one-dimensional (1D) Cu-BTA chains with a π–π/π–d conjugated structure with abundant delocalized electrons (b). In this regard, an optimized Cu-BTA sample with an improved crystallinity (denoted Cu-BTA-H) was prepared at 60 °C for 24 h. For comparison, low-crystallinity Cu-BTA (denote Cu-BTA-L) as well as high-crystallinity Ni-BTA (Ni-BTA-H), which were believed to not have the dual Zn2+ storage features due to the redox-inert feature of Ni2+, were also prepared. The experimental details can be found in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

As depicted in a, Cu-BTA was synthesized by coordinating polymerization of 1,2,4,5-benzenetetramine (BTA) with Cu2+ ions in the presence of ammonia. In this process, the -NH- species are formed by deprotonation of -NH2 in the BTA ligands coordinated with Cu2+ ions in a square and planar manner, forming one-dimensional (1D) Cu-BTA chains with a π-π/π-d conjugated structure with abundant delocalized electrons (b). In this regard, an optimized Cu-BTA sample with an improved crystallinity (denoted Cu-BTA-H) was prepared at 60 °C for 24 h. For comparison, low-crystallinity Cu-BTA (denote Cu-BTA-L) as well as high-crystallinity Ni-BTA (Ni-BTA-H), which were believed to not have the dual Zn2+ storage features due to the redox-inert feature of Ni2+, were also prepared. The experimental details can be found in the Supporting Information.

(c) XRD patterns and (d–f) TEM images of Cu-BTA (-H/L) and Ni-BTA-H powders. (g–i) Full XPS spectra and high-resolution N 1s spectra, Cu 2p spectra, and Ni 2p spectra of Cu-BTA-H and Ni-BTA-H, respectively. (j) EPR spectra, (k) Raman spectra, and (l) FIRT spectra of Cu-BTA-H/-L and Ni-BTA-H.

elements.content: The crystal structure of the materials was first investigated by an X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. As shown in c, all of the XRD patterns are well consistent with previously reported BTA-based c-MOFs with three prominent peaks at 2θ = 20.6, 23.9, and 29.3°, confirming the successful formation of Ni-BTA-H and Cu-BTA-H/L. And the higher diffraction intensities for Ni-BTA-H and Cu-BTA-H indicate their improved crystallinity, compared with Cu-BTA-L, which is helpful for achieving the improved electronic conductivity and structural stability for BTA-based c-MOFs. Correspondingly, Cu-BTA-H shows an aggregated structure with a particle size of 50–100 nm benefiting from the long-range and ordered growth, while Cu-BTA-L generally shows a smaller globular or sheet-like structure with a size of 20–40 nm. Meanwhile, Ni-BTA-H possesses a rod-like structure with a diameter of ∼10 nm, but with a length of over 100 nm (d–f and Figure S1). The rod-like structure for Ni-BTA-H may be induced by the stronger π–π intermolecular interaction owing to the different numbers of d-orbital electrons for Cu (d9) and Ni (d8), leading to the more ordered π–π stacking than in Cu-BTA in the long range. In addition, the corresponding N2 adsorption–desorption results indicate the existence of mesopores around 7.0 and 9.0 nm, possibly formed by the stacking of nanoparticles or -rods in the material, as well as specific surface areas of 25.2 and 71.2 m2 g–1 for Cu-BTA-H and Ni-BTA-H, respectively (Figure S2). These nanosized particles and mesopores would facilitate the ion diffusion inside the materials.

elements.content: The chemical structure and composition of materials were then studied. First, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) survey scans confirm the existence of metal species (Cu and Ni), C, and N elements in the BTA-based c-MOFs; the TEM-based energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mappings of the materials suggest the homogeneous distribution of these elements over the materials (g and Figures S3 and S4). Additionally, the obvious O 1s peaks in the full XPS spectra of both Cu-BTA and Ni-BTA are attributed to the adsorbed oxygen-containing species, e.g., waters or O2, in the unsaturated coordinated metal sites or nanopores in the c-MOFs. In detail, in the high-resolution N 1s XPS spectra, the coexistence of −CN (398.3 eV) and −C–NH–M (399.6 eV, noted as −C–N) peaks indicates the redistribution of electrons between the nitrogen atoms (from −C–NH– to −CN), suggesting the coordination of BTA molecules with metal ions in all the BTA-based c-MOFs, which are also evidenced in the high-resolution C 1s XPS spectra (h and Figures S4 and S5). Noticeably, the high-resolution Cu 2p spectra of Cu-BTA-H and Cu-BTA-L suggest their Cu species possess both +1 and +2 states, while the Ni 2p spectrum reveals only the +2 state of Ni (i and Figure S4). These multivalent Cu ions will act as extra Zn-storage sites for enhanced capacity, which will be discussed later.

elements.content: The strong electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra, with g factors of ∼2.01 and ∼2.08 for Ni-BTA-H and Cu-BTA-H/L (j), respectively, further solidify the existence of delocalized electrons and double-bond characters of −CN bonds. In addition, the −CN and −C–N peaks located at ∼1512 and 1204 cm–1 are also observed in the Raman and FTIR results (k and l), which is consistent with the XPS and EPR results. Noticeably, the peaks at ∼3250 cm–1 in the FTIR spectra are assigned to the -NH- stretching vibration of -NH in secondary amines, while there are two peaks between 3300 and 3500 cm–1 in the FTIR of BTA molecules, assigned to the symmetric and antisymmetric N–H stretching (Figure S6). And, the peaks at ∼620 cm–1 in the Raman spectra corresponds to the vibration of M-N bonds (k), thus collaboratively confirming the formation of M-NH-C- coordination structure between -NH-C- and metal ions. Consequently, the above characterizations confirm the M-NH-C- coordination structure in Cu-BTA with -C = N double bonds and low valence Cu1+ nodes, which would endow the c-MOFs potential dual-mechanism Zn2+ ion storage capability for enhanced reversible capacity.

elements.content: Before the electrochemical performance test, the hydrophobicity of the Cu-BTA-H electrode was first characterized. As shown in Figure S7, the Cu-BTA-H electrode shows a water contact angle of 121°, indicating its good hydrophobicity, potentially favorable for hindering the dissolution of ligands into aqueous electrolytes and enhancing its cycling performance. Subsequently, the cyclic voltammograms (CV) in the range of 0.3–1.6 V at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s–1 of Cu-BTA-H and its analogues were studied. Interestingly, the CV loops of Cu-BTA-H show two cathodic peaks centered at ∼0.81 and ∼0.66 V (a), in which that at ∼0.81 V may be related to the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+ and the other at ∼0.66 V should correspond to the transformation of −CN to −C–N bonds upon Zn2+ insertion. Meanwhile, the two anodic peaks in the broad range of ∼0.93 and ∼1.00 V correspond to the oxidation of −C–N to −CN and Cu+ to Cu2+. In the CV loop of Ni-BTA-H, however, there is only one cathodic peak centered at ∼0.73 V and one anodic peak at ∼0.96 V, corresponding to the reduction and oxidation between −CN and −C–N species upon the intercalation/extraction of Zn2+ (b). The different reduction voltage for −CN in Ni-BTA and Cu-BTA analogues may be related to the coordinated metal ions. Similarly, there are two pairs of voltage platforms located at ∼0.80/1.06 and ∼0.65/0.9 V of Cu-BTA-H/L, and one pair of discharge plateaus at ∼0.73/0.95 V for Ni-BTA-H in the discharging/charging process (c and Figure S8a), which further confirm the dual-mechanism Zn2+ storage feature for Cu-BTA-H/L and the single Zn2+ storage mechanism for Ni-BTA-H.

elements.content: Benefiting from the dual-mechanism Zn2+ storage capability, both Cu-BTA-H and Cu-BTA-L show higher reversible capacities than Ni-BTA-H at different current densities. As shown in d and Figure S8b–d, Cu-BTA-H shows the highest reversible capacities of 330, 200, 180, 160, and 125 mAh g–1 at current densities of 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, and 5.0 A g–1, respectively, while Ni-BTA-H possesses the lowest capacities of 200, 120, 105, 95, and 80 mAh g–1 at these current densities. After being tested for 500 cycles at 2.0 A g–1, a high capacity of 106.1 mAh g–1 can still be achieved on Cu-BTA-H, much higher than those of Cu-BTA-L (77 mAh g–1) and Ni-BTA-H (78 mAh g–1). Of note, the low capacity of Ni-BTA-H is attributed to its intrinsic single-type Zn2+ storage mechanism, while the poorer rate performance and lowest reversible capacity after long cycling of Cu-BTA-L should be induced by the low electronic conductivity and the dissolution of BTA linkers into the electrolytes during repeated discharging/charging processes, because of its low crystallinity. Correspondingly, Cu-BTA-H and Ni-BTA-H with high crystallinity show higher capacity retentions of 68.5% and 84.5%, respectively, than that of Cu-BTA-L (only 51.2%) after 500 cycles at 2.0 A g–1 (e). Of note, the redox of Cu-ions and BTA ligands occurring simultaneously inevitably leads to a poorer stability than that of only via the single redox of BTA ligands, but a largely enhanced crystallinity, even a single-crystal feature of c-MOFs, as well the adoption of modified separators would effectively solve this problem to achieve long-cycling and dual-active c-MOFs based cathodes.
elements.clean_text: Benefiting from the dual-mechanism Zn2+ storage capability, both Cu-BTA-H and Cu-BTA-L show higher reversible capacities than Ni-BTA-H at different current densities. As shown in d and Figure S8b-d, Cu-BTA-H shows the highest reversible capacities of 330, 200, 180, 160, and 125 mAh g-1 at current densities of 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, and 5.0 A g-1, respectively, while Ni-BTA-H possesses the lowest capacities of 200, 120, 105, 95, and 80 mAh g-1 at these current densities. After being tested for 500 cycles at 2.0 A g-1, a high capacity of 106.1 mAh g-1 can still be achieved on Cu-BTA-H, much higher than those of Cu-BTA-L (77 mAh g-1) and Ni-BTA-H (78 mAh g-1). Correspondingly, Cu-BTA-H and Ni-BTA-H with high crystallinity show higher capacity retentions of 68.5% and 84.5%, respectively, than that of Cu-BTA-L (only 51.2%) after 500 cycles at 2.0 A g-1 (e). Of note, the redox of Cu-ions and BTA ligands occurring simultaneously inevitably leads to a poorer stability than that of  only via the single redox of BTA ligands, but a largely enhanced crystallinity, even a single-crystal feature of c-MOFs, as well the adoption of modified separators would effectively solve this problem to achieve long-cycling and dual-active c-MOFs based cathodes.

elements.content: Furthermore, the kinetics of the Zn2+ ion/electron transport in the Cu-BTA-H/L and Ni-BTA-H cathodes were also tested via electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) analyses, which indicated the faster ion/electron transport ability for both Cu-BTA-H and Ni-BTA-H, compared with Cu-BTA-L. Specifically, all of the materials’ Nyquist plots are composed of three parts: two semicircle parts in the high- and medium-frequency regions followed by an inclined line in the low-frequency region, corresponding to the interfacial impedance between the cathodes and the collector, charge-transfer impedance, and ion-diffusion impedance in the cathodes, respectively. The smaller diameters of the semicircles for Cu-BTA-H and Ni-BTA-H in the medium-frequency region indicate the lower charge-transfer resistance than that of Cu-BTA-L (Figure S9), which is induced by the intrinsic high electronic conductivity of the Cu/Ni-BTA-H framework due to the high crystallinity. Interestingly, the larger particle size for Cu-BTA-H does not hinder the ion diffusion properties, and both Cu-BTA-H and Ni-BTA-H show larger slopes for the inclined line in the low-frequency region than that of Cu-BTA-L, indicating their faster Zn2+ ion diffusion rate. A similar result can also be concluded from the lower W 0–R value (500 Ω vs 560 and 739 Ω), larger δ value (20.7 vs 15.7 and 12.7) from the fitted EIS results and faster ion-diffusion coefficient (∼10–10 cm2 s–1 for Ni-BTA-H and ∼10–10 cm2 s–1 for Cu-BTA-H vs 10–11 cm2 s–1 for Cu-BTA-L) from the GITT analysis (Figure S10 and Table S1).

elements.content: Insights into the electrochemical Zn2+ storage behavior of the materials were then investigated by CV at various scanning rates from 0.1 to 2 mV s–1 (f,g and Figure S11). It is found that the proportions of the surface-controlled capacity contributions are as high as 70.5% and 89.4% for Cu-BTA-H and Ni-BTA-H at 2 mV s–1, respectively. This confirms the dominant capacitive-controlled Zn2+ storage mechanism in both materials, which is beneficial to the improvement of rate performance. And the higher capacitive-controlled Zn2+ storage ratio for Ni-BTA-H than that of Cu-BTA-H may be attributed to its larger specific surface area. Consequently, the fast ionic/electronic transport capacity, the dominant capacitive-controlled Zn2+ storage mechanism, and the dual redox active sites for Cu-BTA-H synergistically promote the rate performance and guarantee a high capacity for Cu-BTA-H, which outperforms by far most organic, Cu-based, and MOFs-based cathodes for ZIBs reported (h).

elements.content: To further clarify the Zn2+ storage mechanism of these BTA-based c-MOFs, an ex situ XPS analysis was conducted during the redox process (a and Figure S12). From the XPS survey scan spectra, the alternating intensities of Zn 2p peaks for both Cu-BTA-H and Ni-BTA-H indicate the reversible intercalation/deintercalation of Zn2+ ions during discharging/charging processes (Figure S12). In addition, the intensity of CN species at 398 eV decreases during the discharging process, accompanied by the increased intensity of C–N species at 399.6 eV, as shown in the high-resolution N 1s XPS spectra, which suggests the conversion of −CN to C–N bonds during the discharging process for Zn2+ ion storage. When Cu-BTA-H/Ni-BTA-H are charged to 1.6 V again, the C–N species are both recovered to CN species, indicative of the release of Zn2+ ions in Cu-BTA and Ni-BTA. A similar result was also confirmed by the high-resolution C 1s XPS spectra (b and Figure S13) and the ex situ FTIR spectra for both Cu-BTA-H and Ni-BTA-H materials at different charging/discharging processes (Figure S14).

elements.content: It is worth noting that there is also a reductive transformation of Cu2+ to Cu+ during the discharging process and the reversible oxidation of Cu+ to Cu2+ in the subsequent charging process for Cu-BTA-H (b). Of note, the Cu+ ions will not be further reduced to metal Cu (Cu0), like that of Cu-based inorganic cathodes for ZIBs, which benefits the maintenance of a stable conjugated structure between Cu nodes and HHTP ligands and then contributes to a long cycling performance. In contrast, the divalent state of Ni (i.e., Ni2+) has no such change during the whole charging/discharging process (c), evidencing the inertness of Ni2+ for Zn2+ ion storage. Considering the similar contents of imine (−CNH) species in Cu-BTA and Ni-BTA as the same redox centers for Zn2+ ion storage, the extra capacity of the Cu-BTA materials should be reasonably attributed to the additional redox couples of Cu2+/Cu+, resulting in its higher reversible capacity than for Ni-BTA (d).

elements.content: Furthermore, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out to investigate the redox and electron conductive mechanisms for the BTA-based c-MOFs. First, we calculated the geometries and frontier molecular orbitals of Cu-BTA and Ni-BTA polymeric chains with different repeating units (n = 1–7), including the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) and the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO). As shown in a, the energy gaps between the HOMO and LUMO for Cu-BTA and Ni-BTA are 2.44 and 1.81 eV (n = 1), respectively, which further respectively decrease to 1.47 and 1.22 eV as the repeating units increase to 7 (b). The much lower energy gaps for Cu-BTA/Ni-BTA than for most of the organic electrodes indicate their intrinsically high electronic conductivity benefiting a fast Zn ion storage. Besides, the improved polymerization degree (or higher crystallinity) for the Cu-BTA/Ni-BTA polymeric chains will also contribute to an enhanced total electronic conductivity, which accounts for the enhanced electrochemical performance for the high-crystallinity Cu-BTA.

elements.content: Subsequently, the molecular electrostatic potential (MESP) distribution of Cu-BTA/Ni-BTA, using Cu2-BTA and Ni2-BTA molecules as models, was calculated to identify the possible active sites for Zn storage (c). As shown, the red region represents the positive MESP value (i.e., the nucleophilic center) and the blue region stands for the negative MESP value (i.e., the electrophilic center). Obviously, the sites with more negative MESP are attractive for the uptake of carriers. Thus, the nitrogen atoms in both Cu-BTA and Ni-BTA with a negative MESP are highly active for Zn2+ ion uptake. Then, the theoretical capacities of Cu-BTA/Ni-BTA were further assessed by calculating the sequential binding energy (ΔE) before and after the intercalation of different amounts of Zn ions (d), and the most stable structures with the acceptance of different numbers of Zn2+ ions are shown in e and Figures S15 and 16. Specifically, negative ΔE values of up to 3 mean that the Cu-BTA polymeric chains with two repeating units (Cu2-BTA molecules) can accept up to 3 Zn2+ ions, while Ni-BTA with two repeating units (Ni2-BTA molecules) can only accept up to 2 Zn2+ ions (d,e). Thus, the theoretical capacities of Cu-BTA/Ni-BTA are calculated to be ∼301 and ∼200 mAh g–1, respectively, which are well consistent with the experimental results. And the calculated structural evolution and protonation pathway at the discharging process for Cu-BTA and Ni-BTA are shown in f and Figure S17, respectively.

elements.content: According to previous studies on ZIBs, the fully discharged vanadium oxides and the reduced species (i.e., −C–O−) in the organic cathodes can be spontaneously oxidized by the dissolved O2 in the aqueous electrolyte, thus showing a “self-charging” feature. Similarly, the obvious −CN/Cu2+ peaks in the ex situ XPS analysis in the full-discharging state indicate that the fully discharged species in Cu-BTA-H (i.e., C–N–Zn2+ or C–N–Cu+) may also undergo the same oxidization process. To prove this, the self-charging/discharging behaviors of Cu-BTA-H were further studied. Interestingly, the voltage of the Cu-BTA-H cathode in a coin cell recovers to 0.86 V during a 24 h rest after being discharged to 0.3 V, and the cathode possesses a secondary discharging capacity of 67.6 mAh g–1 (a,b). Meanwhile, the Cu-BTA-H cathode also shows a stable voltage plateau (>1.10 V) during a 24 h rest after being charged to 1.6 V (Figure S18) and the discharge capacity after the same period of rest is almost the same as the charge capacity. Similar results can also be observed for the Ni-BTA-H cathodes (Figures S18 and 19). Consequently, there is a potential self-charging process but without the undesirable self-discharging process during the rest period for Cu/Ni-BTA-H cathodes, and the self-charging performance may be induced by the spontaneous oxidization reaction of the discharged species in Cu-BTA-H/Ni-BTA-H induced by the dissolved O2 in the aqueous alkaline electrolyte after discharging.

elements.content: To confirm this, an open cell with a sufficient O2 supply was assembled. The corresponding voltage–rest time curves and the galvanostatic discharge curves of the discharged cells after different rest periods (i.e., oxidation time) were obtained (c,d). Obviously, the voltage of Cu-BTA-H quickly increases to 0.89 V after only 2 h and then reached 1.10 V after 24 h, which is already higher than the voltage of the major discharging plateau. Meanwhile, the secondary discharging capacities of Cu-BTA-H are also positively correlated with rest/oxidation time, and there is a high reversible capacity of 150.5 mAh g–1, corresponding to 75% of the electrochemical discharge capacity (199.8 mAh g–1 at 0.5 A g–1), obtained after the 24 h rest (d,e). In addition, the recovered high intensities of CN and Cu2+ species in the ex situ N 1s and Cu 2p XPS spectra obtained after the 24 h rest further suggest the oxidation of Cu-BTA-H during the rest process, confirming the self-charging behavior for Cu-BTA-H (f,g). This feature is promising for the development of next-generation self-powered systems.

elements.content: In conclusion, one-dimensional and conductive Cu-BTA has been prepared by coordinating ultrasmall 1,2,4,5-benzenetetramine (BTA) ligands with multivalent Cu ions as the cathode of aqueous ZIBs. The adoption of the small molecule BTA effectively maximizes the redox-active species (−CN−) and minimizes the inactive contents (the benzene group) in Cu-BTA, and the multivalent Cu ions provide a secondary redox of Cu2+/Cu+ for additional Zn2+ storage. These features synergistically contribute to a high Zn2+ storage capacity (330 mAh g–1 at 200 mA g–1). In addition, the high crystallinity, ionic/electronic conductivity, and stable coordination structure of Cu-BTA also leads to an excellent cycling stability and rate capability (106.1 mAh g–1 at 2.0 A g–1 after 500 cycles). Consequently, this work provides a proof-of-concept verification of the significant potential of constructing c-MOFs with dual redox-active sites as high-performance cathodes for ZIBs.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, one-dimensional and conductive Cu-BTA has been prepared by coordinating ultrasmall 1,2,4,5-benzenetetramine (BTA) ligands with multivalent Cu ions as the cathode of aqueous ZIBs. The adoption of the small molecule BTA effectively maximizes the redox-active species (-CN-) and minimizes the inactive contents (the benzene group) in Cu-BTA, and the multivalent Cu ions provide a secondary redox of Cu2+/Cu+ for additional Zn2+ storage. These features synergistically contribute to a high Zn2+ storage capacity (330 mAh g-1 at 200 mA g-1). In addition, the high crystallinity, ionic/electronic conductivity, and stable coordination structure of Cu-BTA also leads to an excellent cycling stability and rate capability (106.1 mAh g-1 at 2.0 A g-1 after 500 cycles). Consequently, this work provides a proof-of-concept verification of the significant potential of constructing c-MOFs with dual redox-active sites as high-performance cathodes for ZIBs.

elements.content: 1D M-BTA (M = Ni, Cu) were synthesized by the coordination polymerization of 1,2,4,5-benzenetetramine (BTA·4HCl) and Ni2+ or Cu2+ ions in the presence of ammonia. For the preparation of Cu-BTA-L and Ni-BTA-H, 0.2 mmol of BTA·4HCl was dissolved in 10 mL of deionized water and stirred for 10 min, as solution A. Then, a solution of 0.2 mmol of NiCl2·6H2O or CuCl2 in 10 mL of deionized water was added to solution A dropwise and stirred a further 10 min. Third, 0.5 mL of a concentrated aqueous ammonia solution (∼14 M) was added to the above mixed solution and stirred for 3 h at room temperature. Finally, the Ni-BTA-H powders were obtained after the powder was washed three times with deionized water and acetone followed by drying at 60 °C under vacuum. Differently, Cu-BTA-H with improved crystallinity was prepared through a mild water bath process. A 26.8 mg (0.2 mmol) portion of CuCl2 was dissolved in 10 mL of deionized water and then added to 10 mL of a BTA·4HCl solution containing 56.8 mg (0.2 mmol) of BTA·4HCl. Second, 0.5 mL of a concentrated aqueous ammonia solution (∼14 M) was added to the above mixed solution and stirred for 30 min at room temperature and water bath treatment for 12 h at 60 °C in sealed bottles. Finally, the Cu-BTA-H powders were obtained after the powders were washed three times with deionized water and acetone followed by drying at 60 °C under vacuum.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Preparation of Cu-BTA-H, Cu-BTA-L, and Ni-BTA-H

1D M-BTA (M = Ni, Cu) were synthesized by the coordination polymerization of 1,2,4,5-benzenetetramine (BTA⋅4HCl) and Ni2+ or Cu2+ ions in the presence of ammonia. For the preparation of Cu-BTA-L and Ni-BTA-H, 0.2 mmol of BTA⋅4HCl was dissolved in 10 mL of deionized water and stirred for 10 min, as solution A. Then, a solution of 0.2 mmol of NiCl2⋅6H2O or CuCl2 in 10 mL of deionized water was added to solution A dropwise and stirred a further 10 min. Third, 0.5 mL of a concentrated aqueous ammonia solution (~14 M) was added to the above mixed solution and stirred for 3 h at room temperature. Finally, the Ni-BTA-H powders were obtained after the powder was washed three times with deionized water and acetone followed by drying at 60 °C under vacuum. Differently, Cu-BTA-H with improved crystallinity was prepared through a mild water bath process. A 26.8 mg (0.2 mmol) portion of CuCl2 was dissolved in 10 mL of deionized water and then added to 10 mL of a BTA⋅4HCl solution containing 56.8 mg (0.2 mmol) of BTA⋅4HCl. Second, 0.5 mL of a concentrated aqueous ammonia solution (~14 M) was added to the above mixed solution and stirred for 30 min at room temperature and water bath treatment for 12 h at 60 °C in sealed bottles. Finally, the Cu-BTA-H powders were obtained after the powders were washed three times with deionized water and acetone followed by drying at 60 °C under vacuum.

elements.content: The morphology and microstructure were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, S4800, Japan) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL-200CX, Japan). The chemical structure and surface composition were determined with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Escalab 250Xi, USA), Raman microscopy (Raman, HR800, Japan) with an excitation laser of 632 nm, and Fourier-transformed infrared spectroscopy (FTIR, Ruili WQF-510, Beijing, China). The crystal structure was confirmed by X-ray diffraction (XRD, D8 Advanced, Germany) using Cu Kα radiation. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption was measured with an Agilent DD2 instrument with a Belsorp-max accessory. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were acquired on a Bruker EMS nano spectrometer at room temperature. The water contact angles were tested on the surface of a Cu-BTA-H electrode film (similar to that in electrochemical tests), via an automatic goniometer/tensiometer 7 (KRUSS, DSA100, Germany).

elements.content: The electrochemical performances of the materials were measured in CR 2032 coin-type cells. The cells were assembled using zinc foil as the anodes. The electrolyte was a 2.5 M ZnSO4 aqueous solution. The cathode was prepared as follows: Cu-BTA-H/Ni-BTA-H powders, Ketjen Black (ECP-600JD), and polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE, 60 wt % dispersion) were mixed in a weight ratio of 7:2:1, and the mass loading of the cathode nanosheet cathode was approximately 1.5 mg cm–2. The galvanostatic charge–discharge tests were carried out on a Land CT2001A battery tester between 0.3 and 1.6 V at different current densities. The galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) was carried out with a pulse current of 0.025 A g–1 for 10 min at 1 h rest intervals. The cyclic voltammogram (CV) test was conducted between 0.3 and 1.6 V using an electrochemical workstation (CHI 660C, Chenhua Instrument Company, China) at scan rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0 mV s–1. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was carried out in a frequency range from 0.1 to 105 Hz.

elements.content: The DFT calculations in this work were performed by using the Gaussian 09 software package with the B3LYP hybrid functional. The atomic structures of Cu2-BTA, Ni2-BTA, Cu2Zn x -BTA, and Ni2Zn x -BTA were fully relaxed at the B3LYP level. The 6-31g basis sets were used for the C, H, N, Cu, Ni, and Zn elements. To evaluate the structure stability of Zn x -BTA, the sequential binding energy, ΔE(x), for x Zn atoms is defined as Δ E ( x ) = E ( Z n x B T A ) − E ( Z n x − 1 B T A ) − E ( Z n ) , where E(Zn x -BTA), E(Zn x–1-BTA), and E(Zn) are the total energies of Zn x -BTA, Zn–‑1-BTA, and a single Zn atom, respectively. The calculated molecular electrostatic potentials (MESPs) were analyzed by the Multiwfn 3.8 programs and visualized by using the Visual Molecule Dynamics (VMD) software.
elements.clean_text:
Computational Details

The DFT calculations in this work were performed by using the Gaussian 09 software package with the B3LYP hybrid functional. The atomic structures of Cu2-BTA, Ni2-BTA, Cu2Zn x -BTA, and Ni2Zn x -BTA were fully relaxed at the B3LYP level. The 6-31g basis sets were used for the C, H, N, Cu, Ni, and Zn elements. To evaluate the structure stability of Zn x -BTA, the sequential binding energy, ΔE(x), for x Zn atoms is defined as      Δ E  ( x )  = E  ( Z   n   x   B T A )  - E  ( Z   n   x - 1   B T A )  - E  ( Z n )     , where E(Zn x -BTA), E(Zn x-1-BTA), and E(Zn) are the total energies of Zn x -BTA, Zn--1-BTA, and a single Zn atom, respectively. The calculated molecular electrostatic potentials (MESPs) were analyzed by the Multiwfn 3.8 programs and visualized by using the Visual Molecule Dynamics (VMD) software.

cln_elements.content:
Aqueous Zn-based batteries (ZIBs) possess huge advantages in terms of high safety, low cost, and environmental friendliness. However, the lack of suitable cathodes with high-capacity, long-cycling, and high-rate capability limits their practical application. Herein, we present a highly crystalline one-dimensional π–d conjugated conductive metal–organic framework by coordinating ultrasmall 1,2,4,5-benzenetetramine (BTA) linkers with copper ions (Cu-BTA-H), as a cathode for ZIBs. The large ratio of active sites and dual redox mechanism of Cu-BTA-H, including the one-electron-redox reaction over copper ions (via Cu2+/Cu+) and the two-electron-redox reaction over organic ligands (via CN/C–N), effectively enhance its reversible capacity. Meanwhile, the abundant porosity, small band gap, high crystallinity, and stable coordination structure of Cu-BTA-H endow it with fast ion/electron transport and effectively hinder the dissolution of organic ligands during cycling, respectively. Consequently, Cu-BTA-H possesses a high reversible capacity of 330 mAh g–1 at 200 mA g–1 and excellent rate performance and long-cycle stability, with a high capacity of 106.1 mAh g–1 at 2.0 A g–1 after 500 cycles and a high Coulombic efficiency of ∼100%. The proposed conductive MOFs with dual redox-active sites provide an efficient approach for constructing fast, stable, and high-capacity energy storage devices.

Regarding this, we herein report a Cu-based c-MOF that is composed of ultrasmall 1,2,4,5-benzenetetramine (BTA) ligands and coordinated copper ions as the cathode for aqueous ZIBs. The adoption of the small molecule BTA effectively maximizes the portion of redox-active species (i.e., −CN−) and minimizes the inactive contents (i.e., the benzene group) in the c-MOFs. Meanwhile, the secondary redox of the transition-metal ions (Cu2+/Cu+) synergistically contributes to an additional capacity for Zn storage. Thus, a high reversible capacity of 330 mAh g–1 at 200 mA g–1 has been achieved for Cu-BTA. In addition, the unique porous structure, high electronic conductivity, and stable coordination structure of Cu-BTA with high crystallinity collaboratively contribute to both a high-rate capability and excellent cycling stability, showing a high capacity of 106.1 mAh g–1 at 2.0 A g–1 after 500 cycles with a Coulombic efficiency of ∼100%. The design of c-MOF-based cathodes with dual 0active sites can thus effectively enhance the energy density and durability of ZIBs.

The crystal structure of the materials was first investigated by an X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. As shown in c, all of the XRD patterns are well consistent with previously reported BTA-based c-MOFs with three prominent peaks at 2θ = 20.6, 23.9, and 29.3°, confirming the successful formation of Ni-BTA-H and Cu-BTA-H/L. And the higher diffraction intensities for Ni-BTA-H and Cu-BTA-H indicate their improved crystallinity, compared with Cu-BTA-L, which is helpful for achieving the improved electronic conductivity and structural stability for BTA-based c-MOFs. Correspondingly, Cu-BTA-H shows an aggregated structure with a particle size of 50–100 nm benefiting from the long-range and ordered growth, while Cu-BTA-L generally shows a smaller globular or sheet-like structure with a size of 20–40 nm. Meanwhile, Ni-BTA-H possesses a rod-like structure with a diameter of ∼10 nm, but with a length of over 100 nm (d–f and Figure S1). The rod-like structure for Ni-BTA-H may be induced by the stronger π–π intermolecular interaction owing to the different numbers of d-orbital electrons for Cu (d9) and Ni (d8), leading to the more ordered π–π stacking than in Cu-BTA in the long range. In addition, the corresponding N2 adsorption–desorption results indicate the existence of mesopores around 7.0 and 9.0 nm, possibly formed by the stacking of nanoparticles or -rods in the material, as well as specific surface areas of 25.2 and 71.2 m2 g–1 for Cu-BTA-H and Ni-BTA-H, respectively (Figure S2). These nanosized particles and mesopores would facilitate the ion diffusion inside the materials.

Before the electrochemical performance test, the hydrophobicity of the Cu-BTA-H electrode was first characterized. As shown in Figure S7, the Cu-BTA-H electrode shows a water contact angle of 121°, indicating its good hydrophobicity, potentially favorable for hindering the dissolution of ligands into aqueous electrolytes and enhancing its cycling performance. Subsequently, the cyclic voltammograms (CV) in the range of 0.3–1.6 V at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s–1 of Cu-BTA-H and its analogues were studied. Interestingly, the CV loops of Cu-BTA-H show two cathodic peaks centered at ∼0.81 and ∼0.66 V (a), in which that at ∼0.81 V may be related to the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+ and the other at ∼0.66 V should correspond to the transformation of −CN to −C–N bonds upon Zn2+ insertion. Meanwhile, the two anodic peaks in the broad range of ∼0.93 and ∼1.00 V correspond to the oxidation of −C–N to −CN and Cu+ to Cu2+. In the CV loop of Ni-BTA-H, however, there is only one cathodic peak centered at ∼0.73 V and one anodic peak at ∼0.96 V, corresponding to the reduction and oxidation between −CN and −C–N species upon the intercalation/extraction of Zn2+ (b). The different reduction voltage for −CN in Ni-BTA and Cu-BTA analogues may be related to the coordinated metal ions. Similarly, there are two pairs of voltage platforms located at ∼0.80/1.06 and ∼0.65/0.9 V of Cu-BTA-H/L, and one pair of discharge plateaus at ∼0.73/0.95 V for Ni-BTA-H in the discharging/charging process (c and Figure S8a), which further confirm the dual-mechanism Zn2+ storage feature for Cu-BTA-H/L and the single Zn2+ storage mechanism for Ni-BTA-H.

Benefiting from the dual-mechanism Zn2+ storage capability, both Cu-BTA-H and Cu-BTA-L show higher reversible capacities than Ni-BTA-H at different current densities. As shown in d and Figure S8b–d, Cu-BTA-H shows the highest reversible capacities of 330, 200, 180, 160, and 125 mAh g–1 at current densities of 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, and 5.0 A g–1, respectively, while Ni-BTA-H possesses the lowest capacities of 200, 120, 105, 95, and 80 mAh g–1 at these current densities. After being tested for 500 cycles at 2.0 A g–1, a high capacity of 106.1 mAh g–1 can still be achieved on Cu-BTA-H, much higher than those of Cu-BTA-L (77 mAh g–1) and Ni-BTA-H (78 mAh g–1). Of note, the low capacity of Ni-BTA-H is attributed to its intrinsic single-type Zn2+ storage mechanism, while the poorer rate performance and lowest reversible capacity after long cycling of Cu-BTA-L should be induced by the low electronic conductivity and the dissolution of BTA linkers into the electrolytes during repeated discharging/charging processes, because of its low crystallinity. Correspondingly, Cu-BTA-H and Ni-BTA-H with high crystallinity show higher capacity retentions of 68.5% and 84.5%, respectively, than that of Cu-BTA-L (only 51.2%) after 500 cycles at 2.0 A g–1 (e). Of note, the redox of Cu-ions and BTA ligands occurring simultaneously inevitably leads to a poorer stability than that of only via the single redox of BTA ligands, but a largely enhanced crystallinity, even a single-crystal feature of c-MOFs, as well the adoption of modified separators would effectively solve this problem to achieve long-cycling and dual-active c-MOFs based cathodes.

Furthermore, the kinetics of the Zn2+ ion/electron transport in the Cu-BTA-H/L and Ni-BTA-H cathodes were also tested via electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) analyses, which indicated the faster ion/electron transport ability for both Cu-BTA-H and Ni-BTA-H, compared with Cu-BTA-L. Specifically, all of the materials’ Nyquist plots are composed of three parts: two semicircle parts in the high- and medium-frequency regions followed by an inclined line in the low-frequency region, corresponding to the interfacial impedance between the cathodes and the collector, charge-transfer impedance, and ion-diffusion impedance in the cathodes, respectively. The smaller diameters of the semicircles for Cu-BTA-H and Ni-BTA-H in the medium-frequency region indicate the lower charge-transfer resistance than that of Cu-BTA-L (Figure S9), which is induced by the intrinsic high electronic conductivity of the Cu/Ni-BTA-H framework due to the high crystallinity. Interestingly, the larger particle size for Cu-BTA-H does not hinder the ion diffusion properties, and both Cu-BTA-H and Ni-BTA-H show larger slopes for the inclined line in the low-frequency region than that of Cu-BTA-L, indicating their faster Zn2+ ion diffusion rate. A similar result can also be concluded from the lower W 0–R value (500 Ω vs 560 and 739 Ω), larger δ value (20.7 vs 15.7 and 12.7) from the fitted EIS results and faster ion-diffusion coefficient (∼10–10 cm2 s–1 for Ni-BTA-H and ∼10–10 cm2 s–1 for Cu-BTA-H vs 10–11 cm2 s–1 for Cu-BTA-L) from the GITT analysis (Figure S10 and Table S1).

Subsequently, the molecular electrostatic potential (MESP) distribution of Cu-BTA/Ni-BTA, using Cu2-BTA and Ni2-BTA molecules as models, was calculated to identify the possible active sites for Zn storage (c). As shown, the red region represents the positive MESP value (i.e., the nucleophilic center) and the blue region stands for the negative MESP value (i.e., the electrophilic center). Obviously, the sites with more negative MESP are attractive for the uptake of carriers. Thus, the nitrogen atoms in both Cu-BTA and Ni-BTA with a negative MESP are highly active for Zn2+ ion uptake. Then, the theoretical capacities of Cu-BTA/Ni-BTA were further assessed by calculating the sequential binding energy (ΔE) before and after the intercalation of different amounts of Zn ions (d), and the most stable structures with the acceptance of different numbers of Zn2+ ions are shown in e and Figures S15 and 16. Specifically, negative ΔE values of up to 3 mean that the Cu-BTA polymeric chains with two repeating units (Cu2-BTA molecules) can accept up to 3 Zn2+ ions, while Ni-BTA with two repeating units (Ni2-BTA molecules) can only accept up to 2 Zn2+ ions (d,e). Thus, the theoretical capacities of Cu-BTA/Ni-BTA are calculated to be ∼301 and ∼200 mAh g–1, respectively, which are well consistent with the experimental results. And the calculated structural evolution and protonation pathway at the discharging process for Cu-BTA and Ni-BTA are shown in f and Figure S17, respectively.

Furthermore, the kinetics of the Zn2+ ion/electron transport in the Cu-BTA-H/L and Ni-BTA-H cathodes were also tested via electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) analyses, which indicated the faster ion/electron transport ability for both Cu-BTA-H and Ni-BTA-H, compared with Cu-BTA-L. Specifically, all of the materials' Nyquist plots are composed of three parts: two semicircle parts in the high- and medium-frequency regions followed by an inclined line in the low-frequency region, corresponding to the interfacial impedance between the cathodes and the collector, charge-transfer impedance, and ion-diffusion impedance in the cathodes, respectively. The smaller diameters of the semicircles for Cu-BTA-H and Ni-BTA-H in the medium-frequency region indicate the lower charge-transfer resistance than that of Cu-BTA-L (Figure S9), which is induced by the intrinsic high electronic conductivity of the Cu/Ni-BTA-H framework due to the high crystallinity. Interestingly, the larger particle size for Cu-BTA-H does not hinder the ion diffusion properties, and both Cu-BTA-H and Ni-BTA-H show larger slopes for the inclined line in the low-frequency region than that of Cu-BTA-L, indicating their faster Zn2+ ion diffusion rate. A similar result can also be concluded from the lower W 0-R value (500 Ω vs 560 and 739 Ω), larger δ value (20.7 vs 15.7 and 12.7) from the fitted EIS results and faster ion-diffusion coefficient (~10-10 cm2 s-1 for Ni-BTA-H and ~10-10 cm2 s-1 for Cu-BTA-H vs 10-11 cm2 s-1 for Cu-BTA-L) from the GITT analysis (Figure S10 and Table S1).

Subsequently, the molecular electrostatic potential (MESP) distribution of Cu-BTA/Ni-BTA, using Cu2-BTA and Ni2-BTA molecules as models, was calculated to identify the possible active sites for Zn storage (c). As shown, the red region represents the positive MESP value (i.e., the nucleophilic center) and the blue region stands for the negative MESP value (i.e., the electrophilic center). Obviously, the sites with more negative MESP are attractive for the uptake of carriers. Thus, the nitrogen atoms in both Cu-BTA and Ni-BTA with a negative MESP are highly active for Zn2+ ion uptake. Then, the theoretical capacities of Cu-BTA/Ni-BTA were further assessed by calculating the sequential binding energy (ΔE) before and after the intercalation of different amounts of Zn ions (d), and the most stable structures with the acceptance of different numbers of Zn2+ ions are shown in e and Figures S15 and 16. Specifically, negative ΔE values of up to 3 mean that the Cu-BTA polymeric chains with two repeating units (Cu2-BTA molecules) can accept up to 3 Zn2+ ions, while Ni-BTA with two repeating units (Ni2-BTA molecules) can only accept up to 2 Zn2+ ions (d,e). Thus, the theoretical capacities of Cu-BTA/Ni-BTA are calculated to be ~301 and ~200 mAh g-1, respectively, which are well consistent with the experimental results. And the calculated structural evolution and protonation pathway at the discharging process for Cu-BTA and Ni-BTA are shown in f and Figure S17, respectively.

cln_elements.content:
To confirm this, an open cell with a sufficient O2 supply was assembled. The corresponding voltage–rest time curves and the galvanostatic discharge curves of the discharged cells after different rest periods (i.e., oxidation time) were obtained (c,d). Obviously, the voltage of Cu-BTA-H quickly increases to 0.89 V after only 2 h and then reached 1.10 V after 24 h, which is already higher than the voltage of the major discharging plateau. Meanwhile, the secondary discharging capacities of Cu-BTA-H are also positively correlated with rest/oxidation time, and there is a high reversible capacity of 150.5 mAh g–1, corresponding to 75% of the electrochemical discharge capacity (199.8 mAh g–1 at 0.5 A g–1), obtained after the 24 h rest (d,e). In addition, the recovered high intensities of CN and Cu2+ species in the ex situ N 1s and Cu 2p XPS spectra obtained after the 24 h rest further suggest the oxidation of Cu-BTA-H during the rest process, confirming the self-charging behavior for Cu-BTA-H (f,g). This feature is promising for the development of next-generation self-powered systems.

Conclusions

In conclusion, one-dimensional and conductive Cu-BTA has been prepared by coordinating ultrasmall 1,2,4,5-benzenetetramine (BTA) ligands with multivalent Cu ions as the cathode of aqueous ZIBs. The adoption of the small molecule BTA effectively maximizes the redox-active species (−CN−) and minimizes the inactive contents (the benzene group) in Cu-BTA, and the multivalent Cu ions provide a secondary redox of Cu2+/Cu+ for additional Zn2+ storage. These features synergistically contribute to a high Zn2+ storage capacity (330 mAh g–1 at 200 mA g–1). In addition, the high crystallinity, ionic/electronic conductivity, and stable coordination structure of Cu-BTA also leads to an excellent cycling stability and rate capability (106.1 mAh g–1 at 2.0 A g–1 after 500 cycles). Consequently, this work provides a proof-of-concept verification of the significant potential of constructing c-MOFs with dual redox-active sites as high-performance cathodes for ZIBs.
